field_edited_text.value:
Vii. IMPROVEMENTS TO NORTHERN ROUTE

The most recent alignment approved by the Planning Commission for
the East-West Expressway is that contained in the 1957 Plan. The com-
plete route is shown on Sheet 6 and the details are presented on Sheets 8
through 19. In the balance of this report this alignment will be referred to
as the Northern Route.

When this alignment was first approved it was intended that the
Expressway would be depressed as it passed through the Mt. Vernon area.
For a period during 1958 it appeared that it would be necessary for this
section to be elevated in order to provide a feasible interchange with the
Jones Falls Expressway. While approval of this elevated structure repre-
sents the last official action of the Planning Commission, the Commission
has subsequently informally agreed that if this alignment is to be used
the Expressway should be depressed through the Mt. Vernon area regard-
less of the interchange complications which might ensue. Subsequent
referrals to the Northern Route will therefore be based upon the depressed
version as approved by the Commission in the 1957 Plan.

In responding to the Mayor’s request for a restudy of the route of
the East-West Expressway, our first efforts were directed at ascertaining
if small-scale improvements could be made in the Northern Route. This
phase of our study was not productive. Only two variations seemed suffi-
ciently worthwhile to warrant serious consideration and only one of these
was studied in detail. These two variations are discussed below:

1. The Hoffman Street Alternate

After crossing the Jones Falls Expressway in an easterly
direction the Northern Route turns to the northeast until it
reaches the blocks between Preston and Hoffman Streets. At
this point it becomes depressed and proceeds between these two
streets to Bond Street. All of the existing improvements between
Hoffman and Preston Streets would be taken. The pattern for

36

this stretch of the Expressway is thus much like that between
Mulberry and Franklin Streets west of Fremont Avenue.

The Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel passes under Hoffman
Street and also under the land just to the south of Hoffman
Street. As a result the land to the south of Hoffman Street is
already cleared of improvements for an average width of about
65 feet. If the bed of Hoffman Street is included there is a
cleared strip of approximately 120 feet.

Certain neighborhood interests which have been opposed to
the East-West Expressway, primarily on the basis of the number
of buildings to be taken, indicated that their opposition would
diminish or disappear if the Expressway could be moved over into
this cleared strip. Since the Pennsylvania Railroad tunnel passes
underneath, the Expressway in this location would have to be
elevated. The results of this small northerly shift in the align-
ment are shown on Sheet 21.

From the standpoint of alignment, grades, ease of access, and
traffic handling ability this possible revision is at least as good as
the original route. It is an improvement over the original route
in the number of houses to be taken. Approximately 380 resi-
dential buildings and 40 other buildings which would have to be
demolished under the original scheme would not have to be taken
if this Hoffman Street alternate were adopted. The Hoffman
Street alternate would also reduce the assessed valuation of prop-
erties to be taken by about $1,500,000.

On the other hand, there are distinct disadvantages to the
Hoffman Street alternate. The original plan called for a depressed
highway between two parallel streets. This is the best possible
arrangement from the standpoint of reducing to a minimum any
